channel.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
channel.description:
Ok, I present my new project, the Cross Language RS webclient... It's basically a basic RS webclient with stealrs and a basic worldswitcher, this provides a base for people to built their webcleints on...
The client is available in 7 languages atm: - Borland Delphi 7 - Microsoft Visual Basic 6 - Borland C++ Builder 6 - Microsoft Visual Basic.NET 2005 - Microsoft Visual C#.NET 2005 - Microsoft Visual C++.NET 2005 - Microsft Visual J#.NET 2005
The project is released under the BSD license which basically allows you to use the code in both open and closed soruce projects, under a license that can be different from the BSD license, however, it also states that you have to credit me either in the source in case of an open source project or in incldued files or somewhere in the rogram in case of a closed source project.
You can download snapshots of my SVN containing all versions of the client here: http://sharesource.org/project/csrswebclient/snapshots/

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @Javacisnotrecognized _^_
item.description:
@Javacisnotrecognized wrote:

Moparisthebest:

Does anyone else find it completely stupid to have source compile to bytecode (or the equivalent thereof) and yet still remain runnable only on one operating system? Why not just compile to machine code, it makes no sense at all.

1: 95% (More or less) people use only that one operating system
2: There is a Unix port

Read full topic

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @moparisthebest Moparisthebest
item.description:
@moparisthebest wrote:

Does anyone else find it completely stupid to have source compile to bytecode (or the equivalent thereof) and yet still remain runnable only on one operating system? Why not just compile to machine code, it makes no sense at all.

Looks good freddy, its nice to see you finally release something open source.

Read full topic

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @frank frank_
item.description:
@frank wrote:

KryptoN_:

[quote=frank_]doesnt .net compile to bytecode?

Na, rather it compiles to its own intermediate language: CIL (Common Intermediate Language). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Intermediate_Language[/quote]FKU THAT IS BYTECODE LUL

they just call it something else so the fact that they are ripping off java is less obvious

Read full topic

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @KryptoN KryptoN_
item.description:
@KryptoN wrote:

doesnt .net compile to bytecode?

Na, rather it compiles to its own intermediate language: CIL (Common Intermediate Language). http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Common_Intermediate_Language

Read full topic

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @Cheese_Police c|p
item.description:
@Cheese_Police wrote:

juju:

just wondering, but what is the point of releasing this work under any license at all, it’s not as if you or anyone else in the world is going to take action against anyone who infringes on it because of its small scale/size. just release it into the public domain.

Tim’s site (ShareSource) will host a project of yours for free, as long as it is open source and licensed.

Read full topic

item.title: [source] Cross Language RS Webclient
item.dc:creator: @Freddy1990 Freddy1990
item.description:
@Freddy1990 wrote:

I’ve so far added support for 3 languages in another IDE, the open source SharpDevelop IDE.
I added:

  • SharpDevelop C#.NET
  • SharpDevelop Visual Basic.NET
  • SharpDevelop Boo.NET

Though the C# and VB versions are the same as for microsoft’s IDE.

Read full topic
